metadata.titleEn: Comprehensive investigation of landslides along the engineering corridor on the northeast edge of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau (2022)_ V1.0
metadata.description: The Engineering Corridors (ECs) in the northeastern margin of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (NE-QTP) include sections of highways, railways, and pipelines that are constructed on permafrost terrain, seasonally frozen ground, and loess. Climate change, earthquakes, and human disturbance are accelerating the degradation of permafrost, causing loess failures, and developing slope instability that leads to numerous freeze‒thaw landslides (FTLs), loess landslides (LLs), and general landslides (GLs). These events often result in road cracks and damage to infrastructure. However, few systematic investigations have been carried out, although many landslides have developed along the ECs. To compile a comprehensive landslide inventory, this study utilizes visual interpretation to identify landslides in the high spatial resolution Gaofen-6 images (2 m) taken between 2021 and 2022, covering an area of 30×104 km2. Then, field investigations were conducted to evaluate the accuracy of the inventory. We identified 11,914 landslides, including 1,095 FTLs, 7,930 LLs, and 2,889 GLs, while 10,825 of the landslides occurred within a 20 km range of the ECs. More specifically, FTLs are relatively rare and show a zonal distribution along active faults and rivers, whereas LLs and GLs have a dense cluster distribution along rivers. In addition, the mean areas of LLs and GLs are larger than those of FTLs. We observed that landslides are prone to develop on north-facing slopes, with steep slopes for LLs and GLs and gentle slopes for FTLs. Moreover, LLs occurred mainly at lower elevations (1500-2300 m), and GLs occurred at medium elevations (2000-3000 m), while FTLs often developed at high elevations (3000-4000 m). These three types of landslides primarily occur in regions that are predominantly covered with meadows, shrublands, and agricultural vegetation. Our inventory is helpful for in-depth research on landslides in the NE-QTP. It will also provide a significant and valuable dataset for quantifying the analysis of landslides along the ECs that are experiencing climate changes, strong earthquakes, and extensive human activities.
metadata.instructions:
File name: The vector file in Shape format contains the boundaries of each landslide. The relevant attribute tables include number, type, latitude and longitude, area (in hectares), elevation (in meters), slope, slope direction, lithology, soil texture, vegetation cover. The corresponding names for the table fields are "FID", "Attributes", "Longitude", "Latitude", "Area", "Elevation", "slope", "Aspect", "Lithology", "Soiltexture", "Vegeta" tion ". "Attributes" includes three categories: "FTLs, Freeze-thaw landslides", "LLs, Loess landslides", "GLs, Genereal landslides". The JPG file is the optical remote sensing image of each landslide (continuously updated), where the file name format is "lands_FID_image name", "FID" corresponds to the vector file.
Data reading mode: Vector data can be opened in ArcGIS or QGIS.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of landslide occurrences along the engineering corridor in the northeastern margin of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: frozen-thaw landslides, loess landslides, general landslides, occur along active faults and rivers, cluster densely along rivers, larger average area, north-facing slopes, steep slopes, gentle slopes, low altitudes (1500-2300m), mid-altitudes (2000-3000m), high altitudes (3000-4000m), grassland, shrubs, agricultural vegetation

Quantification.Question: How many landslides were identified within 20 kilometers of the engineering corridor in the northeastern edge of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Comparison.Question: How does the visual interpretation method for identifying landslides using high spatial resolution images compare to field surveys in terms of accuracy and comprehensiveness in the context of engineering corridors in the northeast of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The visual interpretation method using high spatial resolution images (2 meters from Gaofen-6) allows for the identification of landslides over a large area of 30×104 square kilometers, providing a comprehensive landslide inventory. However, field surveys are necessary to assess the accuracy of the visual interpretation, ensuring the reliability of the identified 11914 landslides, including freeze-thaw landslides (FTL), loess landslides (LLs), and general landslides (GLs). While visual interpretation can cover a vast area efficiently, field surveys provide ground-truth data essential for verifying the accuracy of the remote sensing results.

Interpretation.Question: How can the observed patterns of landslide distribution across different altitudes and vegetation types be interpreted to understand the underlying environmental and geological factors influencing landslide occurrences?
Interpretation.Answer: The patterns show that landslides tend to occur at different altitudes depending on the type, with LLs at lower altitudes (1500-2300m), GLs at middle altitudes (2000-3000m), and FTL at higher altitudes (3000-4000m). This suggests that factors such as temperature, precipitation, and ground stability, which vary with altitude, play a role in landslide occurrences. Additionally, the fact that landslides are prevalent in areas covered by grassland, shrubland, and agricultural vegetation indicates that land cover and land use practices may influence slope stability and susceptibility to landslides.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty of conducting systematic landslide surveys along engineering corridors in the northeastern margin of the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Systematic landslide surveys are challenging due to the accelerated degradation of permafrost caused by climate change, seismic activity, and human interference, leading to the development of slope instability and various types of landslides. Despite numerous landslides occurring along the engineering corridors, there is a lack of comprehensive surveys.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using high spatial resolution imagery from 2021-2022 to identify landslides along engineering corridors on the northeastern margin of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high spatial resolution imagery allows for a comprehensive identification of landslides, which can result in a detailed landslide inventory. This may lead to a better understanding of the distribution and characteristics of different types of landslides, such as FTL, LLs, and GLs. Consequently, it could enhance the accuracy of landslide risk assessments and inform infrastructure planning and maintenance efforts, particularly in areas experiencing climate change, seismic activity, and human disturbances.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of collecting and analyzing high-resolution satellite imagery to identify landslides in areas affected by climate change and human activities?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goals of collecting and analyzing high-resolution satellite imagery to identify landslides are to create a comprehensive landslide inventory, assess the accuracy of these inventories through field surveys, and provide valuable data for analyzing landslides along engineering corridors experiencing climate change, seismic activity, and human interference. This research aims to deepen the understanding of landslide occurrences and characteristics in the northeastern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, facilitating improved infrastructure planning and management.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental and procedural methods can be employed to systematically identify and verify landslides in regions with diverse terrain and environmental conditions, such as the northeastern margin of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To systematically identify and verify landslides in regions with diverse terrain and environmental conditions, high spatial resolution imagery such as the Gaofen-6 satellite images (2 meters resolution) can be visually interpreted to recognize landslides over a large area. This approach can be complemented with field surveys to assess the accuracy of the landslide inventory. The combination of remote sensing and ground truthing helps in compiling a comprehensive list of landslides, accounting for different types such as frozen-thaw landslides, loess landslides, and general landslides, across various altitudes and vegetative covers.
